Review: First printed in 1880, Oats provides a personal -- although not wholly accurate -- account of his experiences in the Andersonville prison camp. An important book for people who want to understand the horrors seen in Civil War prisoner of war camps.

Title: The Civil War Archive: The History of the Civil War in Documents
Review: First published as The Blue and the Gray, this reference work with war-related military, political, and cultural primary sources now has been expanded by Erik Bruun to also encompass race and Reconstruction. With maps, introductions to readings, and an index.

Title: The Civil War Archive: The History of the Civil War in Documents
Review: First published as The Blue and the Gray, this reference work with war-related military, political, and cultural primary sources now has been expanded by Erik Bruun to also encompass race and Reconstruction. With maps, introductions to readings, and an index.

Title: Under the Southern Cross: Soldier Life with Gordon Bradwell and the Army of Northern Virginia
Review: First published in Confederate Veteran magazine, Private Gordon Bradwell's 73 vignettes are collected here for the first time, describing his service with the 31st Georgia at Gettysburg, the Wilderness, Spotsylvania, and Petersburg.

Title: Confederate Wizards of the Saddle Being Reminiscences and Observations of One Who Rode with Morgan
Teaser: Confederate Wizards of the Saddle Being Reminiscences and Observations of One Who Rode with Morgan
Review: First published in 1914, this book describes the most celebrated Confederate cavalry officers in action: Forrest, Stuart, Wheeler, and others. Young was himself a cavalryman under Morgan and recalls battles with clarity and detail.

Title: Disloyalty in the Confederacy
Review: First published in 1934, Disloyalty in the Confederacy makes a convincing case that it is a misconception to think the South was united in its cause. The author, a Mississippian, argues that southern discontent was significant.

Title: James Longstreet: Lee's War Horse
Teaser: James Longstreet: Lee's War Horse
Review: First published in 1936, this work examines the life of one of Robert E. Lee's most trusted commanders. The book remains controversial for its portrayal of Longstreet as an often ambitious and stubborn subordinate.

Title: Civil War Railroads: A Pictorial Story of the War Between the States
Teaser: Civil War Railroads: A Pictorial Story of the War Between the States
Review: First published in 1961, Civil War Railroads features more than 220 black-and-white photographs illustrating the role of railroads, with accompanying text explaining their significance. Included are photographs of trains and stations, trainsmen, and even the Lincoln Funeral Coach.

Title: The Problem of Slavery in the Age of Revolution: 1770-1823
Teaser: Problem of Slavery in the Age of Revolution: 1770-1823 The
Review: First published in 1975, Davis's work is one of the classic statements of the irony between revolutions in the Americas and the continued existence of slavery. This paper edition includes a new preface by the author.

Title: The Maryland Campaign of 1862 and Its Aftermath Civil War Regiments
Teaser: Maryland Campaign of 1862 and Its Aftermath Civil War Regiments The
Review: Firsthand accounts and contemporary essays distinguish this installment of Civil War Regiments devoted to Antietam and its corpse-strewn aftermath. As the narrative of a captured German volunteer in the Union army attests: "A disgusting stench putrefied the air and the screams of wounded men undergoing amputation without chloroform tore at our ears."

Title: Carnival on the Page: Popular Print Media in Antebellum America
Review: Focusing on the "exuberant print culture" that flourished during the pre-Civil War decades, Idabelle Lehuu examines how innovations in publishing like leaflets and lady's books contributed to a public "carnival" of opinions and tastes.

Title: Carnival on the Page: Popular Print Media in Antebellum America
Review: Focusing on the "exuberant print culture" that flourished during the pre-Civil War decades, Idabelle Lehuu examines how innovations in publishing like leaflets and lady's books contributed to a public "carnival" of opinions and tastes.

Title: Gunfire Around the Gulf: The Last Major Naval Campaigns of the Civil War
Teaser: Gunfire Around the Gulf: The Last Major Naval Campaigns of the Civil War
Review: Focusing on the Union's drive to shut down the ports servicing blockade runners in the Gulf of Mexico, Gunfire Around the Gulf highlights the two most important engagements: the Battle of New Orleans and the Battle of Mobile Bay.

Title: Strike the Blow for Freedom: The 6th United States Colored Infantry in the Civil War
Teaser: Strike the Blow for Freedom: The 6th United States Colored Infantry in the Civil War
Review: Follows the 6th Infantry from enlistment and training to fighting the final campaign in Virginia around Petersburg. Filled with many statistical charts and graphs giving demographic information concerning the recruits.

Title: Give Them the Bayonet!: A Guide to the Battle for Henry Hill
Teaser: Give Them the Bayonet!: A Guide to the Battle for Henry Hill
Review: For three hours in July 1861, battle raged on Henry Hill, as part of the First Manassas clash. This guide, complete with an index and bibliography, offers five narrated stops and 20 maps to the War's first serious engagement.

Title: Fort Monroe: The Key to the South
Review: Fort Monroe provided an essential Union toehold in Hampton Roads and  lower Virginia. Illustrated by photos and etchings, this book records the fort's many roles, including hosting the North Atlantic Blockading Squadron and incarcerating Jefferson Davis.

Title: Fort Monroe: The Key to the South
Review: Fort Monroe provided an essential Union toehold in Hampton Roads and  lower Virginia. Illustrated by photos and etchings, this book records the fort's many roles, including hosting the North Atlantic Blockading Squadron and incarcerating Jefferson Davis.

Title: Tampa Before the Civil War
Review: From its earliest origins a military outpost, Tampa was host to "war, vigilante violence, political turmoil, disease, economic calamity, and racial tragedy." Canter Brown, Jr.'s book recreates those pre-Civil War decades.

Title: Tampa Before the Civil War
Review: From its earliest origins a military outpost, Tampa was host to "war, vigilante violence, political turmoil, disease, economic calamity, and racial tragedy." Canter Brown, Jr.'s book recreates those pre-Civil War decades.

Title: Rebel Hart
Review: From the authors of Broken Drum comes the true tale of Nancy Hart, a girl who leaves home to become a Confederate raider. Rebel Hart weaves fact and fiction to bring the tumultuous life of this "ordinary" girl to modern readers.

Title: Sabres, Saddles, and Spurs: The Diary of Lt. Col. William R. Carter, C.S.A.
Teaser: Sabres, Saddles, and Spurs: The Diary of Lt. Col. William R. Carter, C.S.A.
Review: From the war diary entries of Confederate Lieutenant Colonel William R. Carter, Sabres, Saddles, and Spurs, presents the daily activities of a Southern cavalry unit as well as coverage of major cavalry actions at key battles.

Title: At the Right Hand of Longstreet: Recollections of a Confederate Staff Officer
Teaser: At the Right Hand of Longstreet: Recollections of a Confederate Staff Officer
Review: G. Moxley Sorrel, a Georgian who was James Longstreet's aide-de-camp, offers "rough jottings from memory" that present a firsthand perspective on both the War and a retired general who outlived the rest of the Confederate high command.

Title: On Many a Bloody Field: Four Years in the Iron Brigade
Teaser: On Many a Bloody Field: Four Years in the Iron Brigade
Review: Gaff chronicles the history of Company B from the 19th Indiana Volunteers of the storied Iron Brigade. From recruitment to Appomattox, the 19th witnessed some of the fiercest fighting of the war, including Second Manassas and Petersburg.

Title: The Confederate War: How Popular Will, Nationalism, and Military Strategy Could Not Stave off Defeat
Teaser: Confederate War: How Popular Will, Nationalism, and Military Strategy Could Not Stave off Defeat The
Review: Gallagher argues the Confederate nation was never doomed from the start. A more accurate portrayal of Southern attitudes emerges in light of the strength of commitment to the war on the home front, which lasted four years.

Title: Three Days at Gettysburg: Essays on Confederate and Union Leadership
Teaser: Three Days at Gettysburg: Essays on Confederate and Union Leadership
Review: Gallagher joins forces with other leading authorities on Gettysburg and takes the reader through both the controversial and famous -- as well as the equally important but neglected -- aspects that contributed to the outcome and legacy of the battle.

Title: Journey to Cherry Mansion
Review: General Will Wallace, who knows Lincoln intimately and is old friends with Grant, braces himself in Journey to Cherry Mansion for a "slaughter of humanity" at Shiloh that will test his courage and faith.

Title: Glorieta Pass
Teaser: Glorieta Pass
Review: Glorieta Pass follows an Irish immigrant, Unionist dandy, scrappy Texan, and Bostonian lady whose paths converge in the dusty New Mexico Territory where every man is a "freebooter."

Title: Lincoln
Review: Gore Vidal's Lincoln portrays the president not as Father Abraham but as a Machiavellian. First published in 1984 and reprinted here, the novel is part of Vidal's American historical fiction series.

Title: Lincoln
Review: Gore Vidal's Lincoln portrays the president not as Father Abraham but as a Machiavellian. First published in 1984 and reprinted here, the novel is part of Vidal's American historical fiction series.

Title: Soldiers, Sailors, Slaves, and Ships: The Civil War Photographs of Henry P. Moore
Review: Granite state resident Henry P. Moore visually recorded the 48 wartime photos, many of them from South Carolina's Sea Islands, that are collected in this poignant album. A thorough annotation accompanies each image.

Title: Great American Civil War Trivia
Teaser: Great American Civil War Trivia
Review: Great American Civil War Trivia covers hundreds of unique and interesting facts about the politics, personalities, and armies that fought in the Civil War.

Title: Abraham Lincoln the Writer: A Treasury of His Greatest Speeches and Letters
Review: Harold Holzer brings the power of primary sources to young readers in an illustrated volume that contains samplings of Lincoln's sage advice and an extensive chronology of his life.

Title: God Bless General Early
Teaser: God Bless General Early
Review: Harris Mullen's fictional account of what might have happened at Gettysburg features two crafty young Confederate officers who undertake a mission to rustle up some collateral to use as leverage against the Yankees.

Title: Blue & Gray in Black & White: Newspapers in the Civil War
Teaser: Blue & Gray in Black & White: Newspapers in the Civil War
Review: Harris studies Northern and Southern war coverage by exploring "individual and collective efforts" by reporters, the fledgling journalism profession, and battlefield dispatches. Thematic chapters, black and white illustrations, and an exhaustive index are included.

Title: 'Desolating this Fair Country': The Civil War Diary and Letters of Lt. Henry C. Lyon, 34th New York
Teaser: 'Desolating this Fair Country': The Civil War Diary and Letters of Lt. Henry C. Lyon, 34th New York
Review: Henry Lyon later served at Malvern Hill and Antietam, where he was mortally wounded. His wartime journal and letters, literate and perceptive, are annotated and illustrated in this work.

Title: Shades of Blue and Gray
Teaser: Shades of Blue and Gray
Review: Herman Hattaway examines the Civil War from a broad perspective in Shades of Blue and Gray. He focuses on the technological advances that were made and how they affected modern warfare.

Title: The United States Marine Corps in the Civil War: The Third Year
Teaser: United States Marine Corps in the Civil War: The Third Year The
Review: Highlights of this third installment of David M. Sullivan's history of the Corps during the Civil War include their failed attempt to recapture Fort Sumter, their role in subduing New York draft rioters, and their operations in the Pacific.

Title: Abe: A Novel of the Young Lincoln
Review: Historian and novelist Richard Slotkin portrays young Abe Lincoln as a Huck Finn-type character, whose flatbed boat trip down the Mississippi inducted him into adulthood and later political fame.

Title: Honor's Voice: The Transformation of Abraham Lincoln
Teaser: Honor's Voice: The Transformation of Abraham Lincoln
Review: Honor's Voice is a fascinating account of Lincoln's crucial formative years  (1831-1842), revealing a reality that is far more complex, and ultimately more moving, than the legend. A Lincoln Prize Winner.

Title: Imperfect Equality: African Americans and the Confines of White Racial Attitudes in Postemancipation Maryland
Teaser: Imperfect Equality: African Americans and the Confines of White Racial Attitudes in Postemancipation Maryland
Review: Imperfect Equality surveys the evolving status of freemen and ex-slaves in Maryland during the Civil War's aftermath, concluding: "White radicals collaborated with conservatives -- often unintentionally -- to fashion a postwar society that left blacks very much to their own devices."

Title: Antietam
Review: In Antietam, the third book of James Reasoner's Civil War Battle series, commanders of North and South maneuver across the landscape of northern Virginia as the war comes within view of the Brannon family farm in Culpeper County. As the Southern army retreats, Mac is reunited with his older brother, Will, as they witness the reversal of Confederate fortunes.

Title: God Bless General Early
Review: In God Bless General Early, Elizabeth McCall struggles against deprivation and slave upheaval on her South Carolina plantation while her fianc, Captain Ashby Sanders, CSA, fights hopeless battles in Virginia. Will they ever see each other again?

Title: Quilts from the Civil War
Teaser: Quilts from the Civil War
Review: In Quilts from the Civil War, author Barbara Brackman includes complete instructions for assembling nine quilts and discusses the histories of the originals that inspired them.

Title: With Charity for All: Lincoln and the Restoration of the Union
Teaser: With Charity for All: Lincoln and the Restoration of the Union
Review: In With Charity for All, William C. Harris contends that Lincoln's reconstruction program primarily aimed at restoring cooperative Southern self-government rather than winning the War or securing white support for black freedom.

Title: Liberating Sojourn: Frederick Douglass and Transatlantic Reform
Teaser: Liberating Sojourn: Frederick Douglass and Transatlantic Reform
Review: In 1845, Frederick Douglass embarked on an 18-month British lecture and fund-raising tour that ignited abolitionists in England. Essays by William S. McFeely, R.J.M. Blackett, and others probe the trip's significance with respect to race, religion, and gender.

Title: Liberating Sojourn: Frederick Douglass and Transatlantic Reform
Teaser: Liberating Sojourn: Frederick Douglass and Transatlantic Reform
Review: In 1845, Frederick Douglass embarked on an 18-month British lecture and fund-raising tour that ignited abolitionists in England. Essays by William S. McFeely, R.J.M. Blackett, and others probe the trip's significance with respect to race, religion, and gender.

Title: Wilson's Creek
Review: In 1861, Americans questioned which states would join the secession movement and which would remain loyal to the Union. In Missouri, it was largely settled at Wilson's Creek, in a contest that is rightly considered the second major battle of the Civil War. Wilson's Creek provides the first in-depth narrative and analysis of this important but largely overlooked battle.

Title: A Hundred Days to Richmond Ohio's 'Hundred Days' Men in the Civil War
Teaser: Hundred Days to Richmond Ohio's 'Hundred Days' Men in the Civil War A
Review: In 1864 Ohio governor John Brough raised 35,000 men for 100 day regiments, with the intent of freeing up regular soldiers from garrison duty. As these letters and reports record, many instead were thrown into battle at Monocacy Junction and Petersburg.

Title: Lee's Endangered Left: The Civil War in Western Virginia, Spring of 1864
Teaser: Lee's Endangered Left: The Civil War in Western Virginia, Spring of 1864
Review: In a bold gesture, Grant sent his army into the Shenandoah Valley intending to outflank Lee,  until faltering at New Market and Lynchburg's outskirts. This work describes that combat and the hardships imposed on local civilians.

Title: The Impeachment and Trial of Andrew Johnson
Teaser: Impeachment and Trial of Andrew Johnson The
Review: In a timely examination of Johnson's presidential impeachment trial in 1868, the author draws on period records and news accounts to argue that Johnson's threat to nullify congressional Reconstruction policies justified his impeachment.

Title: Wilson's Cavalry Corps: Union Campaigns in the Western Theatre, October 1864 through Spring 1865
Teaser: Wilson's Cavalry Corps: Union Campaigns in the Western Theatre, October 1864 through Spring 1865
Review: In Autumn 1864, General James Harrison Wilson organized Sherman's cavalry into a force that proved itself during Hood's Tennessee invasion and Wilson's later capture of Selma, Alabama.

Title: General William Averell's Salem Raid: Breaking the Knoxville Supply Line
Teaser: General William Averell's Salem Raid: Breaking the Knoxville Supply Line
Review: In Averell's raid on the Virginia and Tennessee Railroad at Salem, the author finds lasting military significance: remarkable drive, determination, and spirit of sacrifice seemed to mark a transition...to a new type of warfare.

Title: Rearing Wolves to Our Own Destruction: Slavery in Richmond, Virginia, 1782-1865
Review: In contrast to plantation slaves, those employed in urban areas (some as bondsmen) participated in the industrialization that occurred during the latter antebellum years. Midori Takagi argues that such advances afforded slaves increasing independence.

Title: To the North Anna River
Review: In his long-awaited third book, Rhea draws on more than 550 published and unpublished sources to chart the game of guile and endurance between Grant and Lee that escalated to a suspenseful draw on Virginia's North Anna River in To the North Anna River.

Title: Tullahoma: The 1863 Campaign for the Control of Middle Tennessee
Review: In late June 1863, the Army of the Cumberland battled against constant rain and Confederate forces to secure all of Tennessee. The hero in Michl R. Bradley's account is Rosecrans, who succeeded through tactical "improvisation."

Title: Beyond the Lines or A Yankee Prisoner Loose in Dixie
Teaser: Beyond the Lines or A Yankee Prisoner Loose in Dixie
Review: In one of the Civil War's first prisoner memoirs published (1864), Geer describes in compelling detail his capture at Shiloh, his trial for "frivolous charges," his incarceration in prison camps and jails, and his harrowing escape and recapture.

Title: Robert E. Lee's Civil War
Teaser: Robert E. Lee's Civil War
Review: In Robert E. Lee's Civil War, military strategist and historian Bevin Alexander recreates, in  fascinating detail, each Civil War battle involving the Army of Northern Virginia, the principal force of the Confederate military.

Title: Silent Thunder: A Civil War Story
Teaser: Silent Thunder: A Civil War Story
Review: In Silent Thunder, a work of historical fiction about two teenage siblings enslaved on a plantation,  Summer and Rosco tell their own stories in period diction. When Rosco escapes through the Underground Railroad, Summer stays with their prayerful mother as news of the Emancipation Proclamation reaches Virginia.

Title: Stonewall's Gold:  A Novel of the Civil War
Teaser: Stonewall's Gold:  A Novel of the Civil War
Review: In Stonewall's Gold, the discovery of a long-guarded secret sends young Jamie Lockhart on the adventure of his life, as the limits of his courage and endurance are tested during the final desperate months of the Civil War.

Title: The Bushwhacker: A Civil War Story
Teaser: Bushwhacker: A Civil War Story The
Review: In The Bushwhacker, a boy and his younger sister attempt to reunite with their family after bushwhackers -- Confederate sympathizers in the Union state of Missouri -- burn down their house.

Title: The Last Full Measure
Teaser: Last Full Measure The
Review: In the concluding installment in the Shaaras' trilogy, Lee, Grant, and Chamberlain wage their final campaigns from the Battle of the Wilderness to Appomattox, where "the killing anger, the hatred, the blind violence of the beast" finally concluded.

Title: The Civil War Archive: The History of the Civil War in Documents
Review: In the same successful format as Our Nation's Archive, The Civil War Archive presents the full story of the War Between the States in documents direct from the minds, pens, and hearts of the men and women who experienced it.

Title: Deo Vindice
Review: In this alternate history of the war, R.W.P. Patterson pulls together battlefield exploits, high seas intrigue, textile factories dependent on cotton, and diplomacy in Washington, Richmond, and several European capitals to create a fast-paced tale that ends with a negotiated peace.

Title: Cincinnati in 1840: The Social and Functional Organization of an Urban Community During the Pre-Civil War Period
Teaser: Cincinnati in 1840: The Social and Functional Organization of an Urban Community During the Pre-Civil War Period
Review: In this reprint of Walter Stix Glazer's 1974 study, the growth of pre-War Cincinnati is examined to reveal the connection between social dynamics and urban development.

Title: Sherman's Other War: The General and the Civil War Press
Teaser: Sherman's Other War: The General and the Civil War Press
Review: In this revised edition, the author explores the battle between Sherman, who wanted censorship of the news media during the Civil War, and newspaper reporters and publishers, who demanded that their First Amendment right to freedom of the press be protected.

Title: Spies and Spymasters of the Civil War, Revised Edition
Teaser: Spies and Spymasters of the Civil War, Revised Edition
Review: In this revised work, Donald E. Markle collects several hundred cases of Civil War male and female spies, from spymasters to newsboys, which are lucidly told through vignettes, photos, and glossary. The work also includes a spy roster containing 432 names.

Title: Rebel Humor: 120 Stories of the Comical Side of Confederate Army Service, 1861-1865
Teaser: Rebel Humor: 120 Stories of the Comical Side of Confederate Army Service, 1861-1865
Review: In this small volume, Coco shows that humor is often timeless. The stories are short and well told, giving a flavor of what the soldiers found funny. We are given the opportunity to see the humanity and personality of the men of the Confederate Army.

Title: The Lost Sword of the Confederate Ghost
Teaser: Lost Sword of the Confederate Ghost The
Review: In this tale written collectively by several primary school students and their teacher, three Columbia teenagers travel back in time to1865 in search of a stolen battle sword. Soon they meet the original owner, and the real trouble begins.

Title: Rituals of Blood: Consequences of Slavery in Two American Centuries
Teaser: Rituals of Blood: Consequences of Slavery in Two American Centuries
Review: In three provocative essays Harvard sociologist Orlando Patterson surveys contemporary black marriages and media images of blacks and argues for an explanatory connection between Southern religion and human sacrifice in the form of postbellum lynchings.

Title: Unlikely Allies: Fort Delaware's Prison Community in the Civil War
Teaser: Unlikely Allies:  Fort Delaware's Prison Community in the Civil War
Review: In three years of operation, Fort Delaware housed 30,000 Confederate men and women with conditions of rampant overcrowding, lack of provisions, and disease.

Title: Gray Ghost: The Life of Col. John Singleton Mosby
Teaser: Gray Ghost: The Life of Col. John Singleton Mosby
Review: Inflicting four times more casualties than his men sustained, John Mosby's guerrilla tactics demoralized Federal troops. Yet, as historian James A. Ramage's exhaustive biography notes, Mosby later became an ardent Republican and Hong Kong consul.

Title: The Debate on the American Civil War Era
Review: Intended for high school and university students, Hugh Tulloch's text offers an English perspective on the American historical profession, slavery, abolitionism, the causes of the Civil War, the War itself, and Reconstruction.

Title: The Debate on the American Civil War Era
Review: Intended for high school and university students, Hugh Tulloch's text offers an English perspective on the American historical profession, slavery, abolitionism, the causes of the Civil War, the War itself, and Reconstruction.

Title: The First Regiment Engineer Troops, P.A.C.S.: Robert E. Lee's Combat Engineers
Teaser: First Regiment Engineer Troops, P.A.C.S.: Robert E. Lee's Combat Engineers The
Review: Jackson details the unit's combat and engineering experiences during the Civil War. Muster rolls, maps, a full index, and several pictures are included in a work that may be of more interest to general readers than to scholars.

Title: A Cigarette Card History of the Generals and Admirals of the Civil War
Review: James B. Duke turned a family business into America's top cigarette company. As a marketing tactic, in 1888 he began distributing brochures with a color portrait and short biography of various Civil War military leaders. This book reprints all 50 brochures.

Title: The Emancipation Proclamation: Abolishing Slavery in the South
Teaser: Emancipation Proclamation: Abolishing Slavery in the South The
Review: James Tackach observes that the Emancipation Proclamation's issuance on January 1,1863, changed the purpose of the Civil War. This indexed work offers a sophisticated discussion of slavery, the War, and Reconstruction.

Title: Appomattox: The Passing of the Armies
Review: James W. Wensyel offers an artful reconstruction of the events preceding and following Appomattox, and the responses of politicians, generals, and soldiers. As in his previous book, Petersburg, Wensyel draws from the factual record.

Title: Freedpeople in the Tobacco South Virginia, 1860-1900
Teaser: Freedpeople in the Tobacco South Virginia, 1860-1900
Review: Jeffrey R. Kerr-Ritchie's fascinating account of postbellum life in Virginia's tobacco country depicts the uncertain social status of former slaves, concluding that "freedpeople managed freedom better than their former masters did."

Title: Freedpeople in the Tobacco South Virginia, 1860-1900
Teaser: Freedpeople in the Tobacco South Virginia, 1860-1900
Review: Jeffrey R. Kerr-Ritchie's fascinating account of postbellum life in Virginia's tobacco country depicts the uncertain social status of former slaves, concluding that "freedpeople managed freedom better than their former masters did."

Title: The Picture Wagon
Review: Joanna Prescott's unionist family is run out of Tennessee. Taking over her wounded father's traveling photography shop, Joanna is soon drawn into intrigue.

Title: The Longest Raid of the Civil War
Teaser: Longest Raid of the Civil War The
Review: John Hunt Morgan's July 1863 raid, which was designed to relieve pressure from Bragg's forces in Tennessee, is exhaustively recollected in this book. The author even includes estimates of the value of various goods stolen by Morgan as he passed through Kentucky, Indiana, and Ohio.

Title: Return to Bull Run: The Campaign and Battle of Second Manassas
Teaser: Return to Bull Run: The Campaign and Battle of Second Manassas
Review: John J. Hennessy's well-written and elegant study, now reprinted, is considered to be the finest on the Second Manassas battle. It presents Hennessy's vivid campaign account and grasp of Second Manassas's importance to the eventual outcome of the War.

Title: The Burning: Sheridan's Devastation of the Shenandoah Valley
Teaser: Burning: Sheridan's Devastation of the Shenandoah Valley The
Review: John L. Heatwole contends that Sheridan's burning of Shenandoah farms and foodstuffs over 13 days in autumn 1864 famished Confederate armies in the field and seared the collective consciousness of the local residents, who included many Anabaptist pacifists.

Title: Duty Faithfully Performed: Robert E. Lee and His Critics
Teaser: Duty Faithfully Performed: Robert E. Lee and His Critics
Review: John M. Taylor's Duty Faithfully Performed: Robert E. Lee and His Critics counters criticisms of recent Lee biographers with a forceful defense of General Lee's character and accomplishments, providing a major counter-revisionist biography of one of the most controversial men in American history.

Title: Southern Unionist Pamphlets and the Civil War
Teaser: Southern Unionist Pamphlets and the Civil War
Review: Jon L. Wakelyn presents 18 pamphlets (and abstracts 22 others) by Southern unionists who opposed secession, including Andrew Johnson, notorious publisher Parson Brownlow, and activist-reporter Anna Ella Carroll.

Title: With Porter in North Missouri
Teaser: With Porter in North Missouri
Review: Joseph A. Mudd's fast-paced history of the 1st Northeast Missouri Cavalry, recruited secretly by Joseph C. Porter, vividly relates how the horsemen avoided Union soldiers who tirelessly pursued them throughout the Trans-Mississippi.

Title: On the Blockade: The Blue and the Gray Series
Review: Just 18 years old, Christy Passford is acting captain of a Union ship assigned to intercept two Confederate blockade runners approaching the southern coast. But before he can capture the ships, Christy must first overcome the obstacles of his youth and a mysterious spy who is lurking around his cabin. Suitable for early teenagers, especially boys.

Title: Nor Shall Your Glory Be Forgot: An Essay in Photographs
Teaser: Nor Shall Your Glory Be Forgot: An Essay in Photographs
Review: Kristoffersen offers a photographic tribute to the Americans who fought in the Civil War and also to the descendants who keep their memories alive through reenactment in Nor Shall Your Glory Be Forgot.

Title: The Complete Civil War Journal and Selected Letters of Thomas Wentworth Higginson
Teaser: Complete Civil War Journal and Selected Letters of Thomas Wentworth Higginson The
Review: Leader of the 1st South Carolina Volunteers, the Union's first black regiment, Thomas Wentworth Higginson kept an extensive journal of his experiences in the army and of its integration. A chronology and index ease the reader's navigation.

Title: The Great War of Destruction
Teaser: Great War of Destruction The
Review: LeVan has assembled primary sources, principally wartime letters and memoirs, to unveil the deliberations and outcomes of Confederate military operations.

Title: Yankee Spy
Teaser: Yankee Spy
Review: Louisa, a young war widow, is a Union spy. She is betrayed at the end, but not before appreciating the human side to Confederate soldiers: "They, too, believed in their principles and they, too, were brave, honorable men."

Title: Lincoln's Sacred Effort: Defining Religion's Role in American Self-Government
Review: Lucas E. Morel contends that Lincoln "displayed an acute awareness of the reciprocal relationship between religion and politics." This book considers the influence of Christianity and morality on Lincoln's statesmanship.

Title: Memoirs of a Confederate Staff Officer: From Bethel to Bentonville
Teaser: Memoirs of a Confederate Staff Officer: From Bethel to Bentonville
Review: Major James Ratchford participated in 35 major battles as adjutant to generals Hill, Hood, and Stephen Lee. This concise memoir includes amusing vignettes witnessed by Ratchford, including the time Jubal Early's staff conspired to intoxicate the general.

Title: The Civil War for Kids: A History with 21 Activities
Teaser: Civil War for Kids: A History with 21 Activities The
Review: Making butternut dye for uniforms, decoding wigwag, and baking hardtack are only a few of the activities that will bring history to life. The Civil War for Kids: A History with 21 Activities makes a wonderful gift.

Title: Vicksburg: The Battle That Won the Civil War
Teaser: Vicksburg: The Battle That Won the Civil War
Review: Maps, photos, and drawings illustrate this history of Vicksburg, which chronicles the lives of civilians and soldiers alike during what Confederate General Dabney Maury called "the grandest spectacle of my life." Includes glossary.

Title: Civil Rights Pioneer: A Story about Mary Church Terrell
Teaser: Civil Rights Pioneer: A Story about Mary Church Terrell
Review: Mary Church, born in Memphis in 1863, attended Oberlin during the final years of Reconstruction and became an educator, lecturer, and author. She lived into the early Civil Rights era. This biography is for ages 8-13.

Title: Grant Wins the War: Decision at Vicksburg
Teaser: Grant Wins the War: Decision at Vicksburg
Review: Meticulously researched and insightful, James R. Arnold's analysis of the Vicksburg campaign concludes with Lincoln's triumphant remark that Grant's victory ensured that "the Father of Waters again goes unvexed to the sea." New in softcover.

Title: Strange but True Civil War Stories
Teaser: Strange but True Civil War Stories
Review: More than 20 Civil War vignettes are presented by Nancy Clayton in dialogue accessible to children aged 8-12. A short glossary follows such tales as "Dabney's Clothesline Telegraph" and "The Last Cow in the County."

Title: Chronicles of the Civil War: An Illustrated History of the War Between the States
Teaser: Chronicles of the Civil War: An Illustrated History of the War Between the States
Review: More than 300 photographs, illustrations, paintings, and maps have been assembled by two former military servicemen to produce the stunning Chronicles of the Civil War: An Illustrated History of the War Between the States.

Title: Stonewall's Gold: A Novel of the Civil War
Teaser: Stonewall's Gold: A Novel of the Civil War
Review: Mrazek, a former congressman who championed Civil War battlefield preservation, turns his attention to fiction. The result is a teenage boy's coming-of-age search for Confederate gold buried amidst the desolation of the Shenandoah Valley after Sheridan.

Title: For Home and the Southland: A History of the 48th Georgia Infantry Regiment
Teaser: For Home and the Southland: A History of the 48th Georgia Infantry Regiment
Review: Mustered in east central Georgia, the 48th Regiment served in the Army of Northern Virginia from early 1862 through Appomattox Court House. John Zwemer's introductory essay is followed by maps, a unit roster, biographical sketches, and bibliography.

Title: Soldiers at the Doorstep: Civil War Lore
Teaser: Soldiers at the Doorstep: Civil War Lore
Review: Nearly 20 Southern oral tales from Virginia have been set to written form in Larry S. Chowning's collection. Introductions and illustrations are provided for vignettes such as "Mrs. Kelly's Cow," "A Christmas Ham," and "Yankee Hole."

Title: Nelson County: A Portrait of the Civil War
Teaser: Nelson County: A Portrait of the Civil War
Review: Nelson County, Kentucky, was occupied early by Union forces but nevertheless sent many of its sons south to fill Confederate ranks. Bragg's 1862 occupation of Bardstown and Morgan's raids are recounted through Dixie Hibbs's narration and some 200 photos.

Title: Deep in the Heart
Teaser: Deep in the Heart
Review: Newlywed Wiley Nesmith departed to defend "The Cause," promising his young wife a swift return. But things didn't go according to plan. Deep in the Heart is based on a true story.

Title: Science, Race, and Religion in the American South: John Bachman and the Charleston Circle of Naturalists, 1815-1895
Teaser: Science, Race, and Religion in the American South: John Bachman and the Charleston Circle of Naturalists, 1815-1895
Review: Nineteenth-century Charleston was a site of important scientific advances. Its naturalists divided over the origin and significance of racial differences, but most supported the War that ultimately retarded further scientific progress in the South.

Title: North Across the River: A Civil War Trail of Tears
Teaser: North Across the River: A Civil War Trail of Tears
Review: North Across the River traces the compelling stories of the Stewarts and other families who were forced to leave their homes in Georgia as part of a mass deportation of Confederate civilians.

Title: A Guide to Civil War Sites in Maryland: Blue and Gray in a Border State
Teaser: Guide to Civil War Sites in Maryland: Blue and Gray in a Border State A
Review: Not much escapes the attention of this guide to Maryland battlefields, homes, and sites involved with the Civil War. Some are well-trodden, but others -- like Frederick's War Correspondents Arch and the statue of Phillipides -- merit a closer look.

Title: Goodbye, Boys! Goodbye!: A Walking Guide to the High Water Mark, Gettysburg
Teaser: Goodbye, Boys! Goodbye!: A Walking Guide to the High Water Mark, Gettysburg
Review: Noting seven recommended stops, this book guides the reader in a walk that helps to reconstruct the fighting at the "High Water Mark" during July 2-3, 1863.

Title: We're Going in There: A Guide to the Battles for Little Round Top -- Valley of Death -- Devil's Den
Teaser: We're Going in There: A Guide to the Battles for Little Round Top -- Valley of Death -- Devil's Den
Review: Noting ten recommended stops that illuminate the action that occurred on July 1, 1863, this book guides the reader through some of the most visited spots on the Gettysburg battlefield.

Title: Sword and Olive Branch: Oliver Otis Howard
Teaser: Sword and Olive Branch: Oliver Otis Howard
Review: Of solid Yankee stock, Oliver Otis Howard was a brave general better remembered for his postwar activities: Freedman' Bureau commissioner; West Point superintendent; founder of two universities. A reprint of John Carpenter' 1964 biography.

Title: Of Men and Muskets: Stories of the Civil War
Teaser: Of Men and Muskets: Stories of the Civil War
Review: Organized by themes such as "Before the Fighting" and "The Grim Final Years," Of Men and Muskets contains snappy, entertaining vignettes about famous and obscure Civil War personalities.

Title: Aunt Clara Brown: Official Pioneer
Review: Original paintings with a folk art flair illustrate this short biography written for beginning readers, the story of a slave who bought her freedom, moved to Colorado, and then helped to resettle other former slaves.

Title: Aunt Clara Brown: Official Pioneer
Review: Original paintings with a folk art flair illustrate this short biography written for beginning readers, the story of a slave who bought her freedom, moved to Colorado, and then helped to resettle other former slaves.

Title: The Divided Union: A Concise History of the Civil War
Review: Over 100 black-and-white photos and color plates accompany text that surveys the Civil War, from its causes to its legacy. Written in accessible prose, The Divided Union also features a bibliography and index.

Title: The Memorial War Book
Review:
Over 2000 maps, etchings, and battle scenes are included in this digital reprint of Union correspondent George F. William's 1894 Memorial War Book, which offers soldier narratives alongside photos by Brady, Gardner, and others.

available by calling 360.961.3768

Title: Libby Prison & Beyond: A Union Staff Officer in the East, 1862-1865
Teaser: Libby Prison & Beyond: A Union Staff Officer in the East, 1862-1865
Review: Over 250 journal entries and letters of Robert Thompson Cornwall are collected to depict his military service in the 67th Pennsylvania, his nine month imprisonment in Libby Prison, and his staff work with Rickett's Sixth Corps at Monocacy.

Title: Sherman's Civil War: Selected Correspondence of William T. Sherman, 1860-1865
Teaser: Sherman's Civil War: Selected Correspondence of William T. Sherman, 1860-1865
Review: Over 400 letters, many published for the first time, convey Sherman's thoughts on various issues and people. Sherman's Civil War: Selected Correspondence of William T. Sherman, 1860-1865 includes passages written about Ulysses S. Grant and Abraham Lincoln.
Publisher: The University of North Carolina Press

Title: Sherman's Civil War: Selected Correspondence of William T. Sherman, 1860-1865
Teaser: Sherman's Civil War: Selected Correspondence of William T. Sherman, 1860-1865
Review: Over 400 letters, many published for the first time, convey Sherman's thoughts on various issues and people. Sherman's Civil War: Selected Correspondence of William T. Sherman, 1860-1865 includes passages written about Ulysses S. Grant and Abraham Lincoln.
Publisher: The University of North Carolina Press

Title: By the Blood of Our Alumni: Norwich University Citizen Soldiers in the Army of the Potomac
Teaser: By the Blood of Our Alumni: Norwich University Citizen Soldiers in the Army of the Potomac
Review: Overshadowed by West Point, Norwich University nevertheless contributed 700 graduates to Union ranks and over 50 to Confederate ones, and they did honor to the Vermont school's name from Bull Run to Petersburg. Appendices document the individual alumni.

Title: In Camp and Battle with the Washington Artillery of New Orleans
Teaser: In Camp and Battle with the Washington Artillery of New Orleans
Review: Owen served as adjutant of Louisiana's Washington Artillery battalion. An index new in this edition makes the depictions of officers (especially Longstreet), battles, and camp life even more accessible.

Title: A Lifetime's Devotion': Baton Rouge Through the Eyes of Photographer Andrew D. Lytle, 1857-1917
Review: Packed with over 500 photos shot from the camera of Andrew D. Lytle, this CD-ROM collection presents photos of Baton Rouge residents, architecture, and landscape during the Civil War and from the postbellum decades.

Title: William G. Brownlow: Fighting Parson of the Southern Highlands
Teaser: William G. Brownlow: Fighting Parson of the Southern Highlands
Review: Parson Brownlow was an original. His fiery sermons, newspaper columns, and gubernatorial speeches advocated prohibition, Methodism, Whiggery, the Union, and slavery. He assailed his adversaries and they reciprocated. This reprint of a classic work features Stephen V. Ash's introduction.

Title: Brink of Destruction: A Quotable History of the Civil War
Teaser: Brink of Destruction: A Quotable History of the Civil War
Review: Photos and brief introductions precede sections organized chronologically that together contain over 300 quotes from Civil War politicians, generals, soldiers, and civilians. Some common, others obscure, these quips and reflections record the development of war.

Title: Stopping Pickett: The History of the Philadelphia Brigade
Teaser: Stopping Pickett : The History of the Philadelphia Brigade
Review: Pickett's charge at Gettysburg was partly repulsed by the heady Philadelphia Brigade. Stopping Pickett includes illustrations, indices, and maps.

Title: Angel Trumpet: A Civil War Mystery
Teaser: Angel Trumpet: A Civil War Mystery
Review: Picking up where her Dead March left off, Ann McMillan's Angel Trumpet unleashes two unlikely sleuths -- a young white widow and a black freewoman herbalist -- to discover why Colonel John Berton's "ancestral home had been turned into a slaughterhouse."

Title: The Gates of Light: A Story of the American Civil War
Review: Placing his own ancestors in the thick of the Civil War's greatest battles, novelist J. Prescott Johnson combines fact with fiction, utilizing the experiences of five brothers and a sister from a Maine family to humanize the conflict even while considering its philosophical dimensions.

Title: Impeachment of a President: Andrew Johnson, the Blacks, and Reconstruction
Teaser: Impeachment of a President: Andrew Johnson, the Blacks, and Reconstruction
Review: Portraying Andrew Johnson as a genuine Unionist but also a crafty conservative dedicated to preserving the South's social order, historian Hans Trefousse suggests that the Republicans' failure to remove Johnson doomed Radical Reconstruction.

Title: Beneath the Waters: A Guide to Civil War Shipwrecks
Teaser: Beneath the Waters: A Guide to Civil War Shipwrecks
Review: Presented in an easy-to-understand format, Hemphill's work provides the general location, class, armament, cargo, citation in the naval War of the Rebellion collection, and dates for hundreds of Union and Confederate warships and merchant vessels lost at sea.

Title: Inside Lincoln's White House: The Complete Civil War Diary of John Hay
Teaser: Inside Lincoln's White House: The Complete Civil War Diary of John Hay
Review: Previously available in two prior editions from other publishers, this edition of the diary of assistant presidential secretary John Hay is presented in paperback and provides an intimate account of the turbulent war years during Lincoln's presidency and closely profiles Lincoln from Hay's insider perspective.

Title: A Yankee at Arms: The Diary of Lieutenant Augustus D. Ayling, 29th Massachusetts Volunteers
Teaser: Yankee at Arms: The Diary of Lieutenant Augustus D. Ayling, 29th Massachusetts Volunteers A
Review: Previously unpublished, Augustus Ayling's literate and candid diary records his observations about the battle between the Monitor and the Merrimack, the Peninsula campaign, Vicksburg, early occupation duty in Richmond, and more.

Title: Balancing Evils Judiciously: The Pro-Slavery Writings of Zephaniah Kingsley
Review: Pro-slavery but anti-racist, Zephaniah Kingsley (1765-1843) pushed for Florida to adopt a three-caste society of whites, freed blacks, and slaves. Annotated by Daniel W. Stowell, this edition of Kingsley's writings features an introduction by Eugene Genovese.

Title: Culture of Eloquence: Oratory and Reform in Antebellum America
Review: Profiles of Emerson, Elizabeth Peabody, Walt Whitman, and other culture figures reveal the influence of transcendentalism and naturalism on the antebellum oratory that the Lyceum Movement helped nurture.

Title: A Light and Uncertain Hold: A History of the Sixty-Sixth Ohio Volunteer Infantry
Teaser: Light and Uncertain Hold: A History of the Sixty-Sixth Ohio Volunteer Infantry A
Review: Provides a military history of the 66th Ohio Volunteer Infantry and a poignant social history of the unit's home, Champaign County, Ohio, during the Civil War.

Title: A Texas Cavalry Officer's Civil War: The Diary and Letters of James C. Bates
Teaser: Texas Cavalry Officer's Civil War: The Diary and Letters of James C. Bates A
Review: Publication of James C. Bates's letters and diary treats scholars to a documentary treasure trove and all readers to a fresh, first-person dose of American history. Edited by Richard Lowe, A Texas Cavalry Officer's Civil War: The Diary and Letters of James C. Bates contains chilling accounts of combat and a running narrative of life in camp and on campaign.

Title: Any Known Blood
Teaser: Any Known Blood
Review: Pursuing his genealogy, Langston Cane V, a man of mixed race, travels south from Canada. But the task is complicated by romantic interests and an uncooperative aged Baltimore aunt.

Title: It Has Seamed Like War Today: The Civil War Letters of William D. Walton
Review: Quaker medic William Walton's 32 letters collected here address such subjects as Antietam's carnage, personal finances, and Professor Lowe's balloon.

Title: The Civil War: Unstilled Voices
Teaser: Civil War: Unstilled Voices The
Review: Readers will actually hold replicas of memorable photographs, moving letters, and monumental newspaper clippings and documents, all found in The Civil War: Unstilled Voices, an interactive, three-dimensional collection of history.

Title: With the 3rd Wisconsin Badgers: The Living Experience of the Civil War Through the Journals of Van R. Willard
Teaser: With the 3rd Wisconsin Badgers: The Living Experience of the Civil War Through the Journals of Van R. Willard
Review: Reflections on liberty, religion, and mortality are found in Willard's journals, expertly annotated by Steven S. Raab. Willard participated in 17 major battles between 1861 and 1864.

Title: Nor Shall Your Glory Be Forgot: An Essay in Photographs
Teaser: Nor Shall Your Glory Be Forgot: An Essay in Photographs
Review: Rendered in black-and-white photos that range from clear to impressionistic to grainy, reenactors are shown in camp, battle formation, conflict, glory, and sometimes final agony. Includes an introduction by Brian C. Pohanka and quotes from historical combatants.

Title: One of Lee's Best Men: The Civil War Letters of General William Dorsey Pender
Teaser: One of Lee's Best Men: The Civil War Letters of General William Dorsey Pender
Review: Reprinted letters of Pender, who partici-pated in and was killed during Pickett's epic charge. The collection provides insights on Southern generals from Lee to A.P. Hill, and also features affectionate correspondence with his wife Fanny. New foreword by Brian Wills.

Title: USS "New Ironsides" in the Civil War
Teaser: USS "New Ironsides" in the Civil War
Review: Roberts not only discusses the design, construction, and wartime service of the U.S.S. New Ironsides, but also explains why the government ultimately decided to build Monitor-class ironclads rather than more powerful ships like the New Ironsides.

Title: While the Banshee Cried: The Demise of the Irish Brigade in the American Civil War
Teaser: While the Banshee Cried: The Demise of the Irish Brigade in the American Civil War
Review:
Self-published [available through Otto Bookstore at 888-762-4526]

Following the fictitious Nolen family's trajectory, this novel romps around Ireland before describing how the Nolens make their way to a country beset by a war that ultimately divides the family members themselves.

Title: Selina and the Shoo-Fly Pie
Teaser: Selina and the Shoo-Fly Pie
Review: Selina and her family are Mennonites who relocated in Canada to escape the War. But the conflict comes to them when Selina's grandmother and troubled cousin visit from Philadelphia. Written for ages 5-8, Barbara Smucker's novel is colorfully illustrated and includes a recipe for the grandmother's Shoo-Fly pie.

Title: The Civil War on the Lower Kansas-Missouri Border
Review: Set in a geographical area where today four states meet, this nonfiction work examines local raids and battles (including those at Carthage, Mine Creek, Baxter Springs) and describes such figures as John Coffee, Tom Livingston, and Sterling Price. Indexed.

Title: The Hearts of Soldiers: A Novel
Teaser: Hearts of Soldiers: A Novel The
Review: Set in the towns of War, West Virginia, and Gettysburg, The Heart of Soldiers is a contemporary novel that grapples with love and infidelity, truth and memory, against the backdrop of the Civil War, Vietnam, and the 1960s.

Title: Road to Freedom (Between Two Flags Series, No. 4)
Teaser: Road to Freedom (Between Two Flags Series, No. 4)
Review: Set in Virginia, this young adult novel examines the Civil War from the perspective of three interconnected teenagers. Gideon lives with his widowed mother, Emily is a unionist from Illinois who is detained on her relatives' plantation, and Nat is a slave who draws strength from knowing:  "Winning was in the mind and not the muscles."

Title: Civil War Generals in Defeat
Teaser: Civil War Generals in Defeat
Review: Seven different authors profile both Confederate and Union generals in relation to a battlefield loss. Each essay interweaves personality, logistics, and unforeseen circumstances as contributing factors which helped shape battlefield outcomes.

Title: No Band of Brothers: Problems of the Rebel High Command
Teaser: No Band of Brothers: Problems of the Rebel High Command
Review: Several of Steven E. Woodworth's previously published articles and two of his lectures are compiled here to show that little harmony existed in the highest echelons of the Confederate government and military. Jefferson Davis provides the focal point for No Band of Brothers.

Title: From the Ashes of Ruin
Teaser: From the Ashes of Ruin
Review: Sherman's Georgia march fails to break Ellen Heyward's spirit, which is demonstrated as she evades capture by a Union officer whose relentless pursuit becomes both a romantic and professional imperative in this novel.

Title: Sherman's Horseman: Union Cavalry Operations in the Atlanta Campaign
Teaser: Sherman's Horseman: Union Cavalry Operations in the Atlanta Campaign
Review: Sherman's Horsemen is a powerful narrative filled with informative maps and photographs. It thoroughly details the vital role of horse soldiers in the western theater and provides a view of Sherman's cavalry commanders.

Title: Red River Steamboats: Images of America
Teaser: Red River Steamboats: Images of America
Review: Shreveport, the Confederate capital of Louisiana, is situated along the Red River, which invited a string of Civil War naval battles. This generously illustrated book collects photos of participating transport vessels, hospital ships, ironclads, and gunboats.

Title: A Colored Man Round the World
Teaser: Colored Man Round the World A
Review: Slave David F. Dorr travelled overseas between 1851 and 1854 with his owner. This travelogue, published in 1858 after Dorr fled north, is written in a Victorian style in what Malini Johar Schueller's introduction terms "literary doublespeak: the blackest of texts in whiteface."

Title: A Colored Man Round the World
Teaser: Colored Man Round the World A
Review: Slave David F. Dorr travelled overseas between 1851 and 1854 with his owner. This travelogue, published in 1858 after Dorr fled north, is written in a Victorian style in what Malini Johar Schueller's introduction terms "literary doublespeak: the blackest of texts in whiteface."

Title: Drawn to the Civil War
Teaser: Drawn to the Civil War
Review: Snappy profiles and cutting caricatures of over 60 Civil War era personalities make for delightful reading. Richard Ewell is described as a "bald and lisping rebel bird" and Mary Todd Lincoln is dubbed a "hellcat and flower child."

Title: The Abolitionists & the South: 1831-1861
Review: Stanley Harrold considers the reception and influence of abolitionism in the antebellum South, concluding that the movement featured a diversity of rhetoric and strategies, and drew its inspiration from both sides of the Mason-Dixon.

Title: Don Carlos Buell: Most Promising of All
Teaser: Don Carlos Buell: Most Promising of All
Review: Stephen D. Engle's biography of Buell, the Union general whose shining moment at Shiloh was eclipsed by his failure to reverse Bragg's 1862 invasion of Tennessee and Kentucky, depicts Buell's personal clashes with Andrew Johnson.

Title: A Black Patriot and a White Priest: Andr Cailloux and Claude Paschal Maistre in Civil War New Orleans
Review: Stephen J. Ochs reveals the unlikely circumstances that led to a defiant French-born abolitionist priest in New Orleans presiding at the funeral for an Afro-Creole captain in the 1st Louisiana Native Guards who perished at Port Hudson.

Title: The American Civil War: Cultures in Conflict
Review: Steven E. Woodworth gets at the heart of the Civil War - the United States had become "a nation containing two cultures that were increasingly distinct" - in this narrated selection of primary source letters, diaries, and memoirs.

Title: Petersburg: Out of the Trenches
Teaser: Petersburg: Out of the Trenches
Review: Stylistically innovative, Wensyel's work of historical fiction takes place in the final days of the Petersburg siege as real participants describe -- in their own words or those the author ascribes to them -- the unfolding events.

Title: North Carolina: The Final Battles Civil War Regiments
Teaser: North Carolina: The Final Battles Civil War Regiments
Review: Succinct and informative, North Carolina: The Final Battles traces the road to Bentonville through essays on the battles of Town Creek, Averasboro, Wilmington, and the U.S. Colored Infantry's engagements in Virginia and North Carolina.

Title: The Civil War Source Book
Teaser: Civil War Source Book The
Review: Succinct entries on campaigns, weapons, military life, troops, and generals make this work essential for any reference shelf. Photos, tables, and excerpts from diaries and letters are included, along with a helpful glossary and index.

Title: The Soul of Battle: From Ancient Times to the Present Day, How Three Great Liberators Vanquished Tyranny
Teaser: Soul of Battle: From Ancient Times to the Present Day, How Three Great Liberators Vanquished Tyranny The
Review: Swiftly summoned and disbanded armies "aimed at salvation and liberation, not conquest and enslavement" have won the most crushing victories, Victor Hanson argues in this book featuring William Sherman as a "great liberator."

Title: Volunteers for Glory
Teaser: Volunteers for Glory
Review: Teenage recruit Paddy Mulcahy distinguishes himself on the battlefield until he is hospitalized in New York, just in time to witness the 1863 draft riots. He recovers to rejoin the 118th Pennsylvania Regiment.

Title: Black Flag: Guerilla Warfare on the Western Border, 1861-1865
Teaser: Black Flag: Guerilla Warfare on the Western Border, 1861-1865
Review: Tensions between pro-slave and pro-free state Midwesterners preceded, and indeed precipitated the Civil War; its outbreak simply unleashed a torrent of bloodshed by bushwhackers, jayhawkers, and vigilantes, as this accessible volume brings to life.

Title: The Class of 1846: From West Point to Appomattox: Stonewall Jackson, George McClellan and Their Brothers
Teaser: Class of 1846: From West Point to Appomattox: Stonewall Jackson, George McClellan and Their Brothers The
Review: The 122 cadets in West Point's Class of 1846 eventually numbered among themselves twenty generals and engaged in combat in three wars. Waugh has written a colorful collective biography of these friends and sometimes foes.

Title: Touched by Fire: Letters from Company D, 5th Texas Infantry, Hood's Brigade
Review: The annotated letters of three "Waverly Confederates" collected in Touched by Fire reveal a different fate for each Texan: one, a private, fought until Appomattox; another, a senator's son, perished at the Wilderness; the third, the company's commander, was captured at Gettysburg.

Title: Beechers, Stowes, and Yankee Strangers: The Transformation of Florida
Teaser: Beechers, Stowes, and Yankee Strangers: The Transformation of Florida
Review: The arrival of prominent Yankees -- including Harriet Beecher Stowe and her brother, Charles Beecher -- during Reconstruction brought far-reaching education and social reforms to Florida, foreshadowing the 20th century influx of Northern tourists and retirees.

Title: All the Laws But One Civil Liberties in Wartime
Teaser: All the Laws But One Civil Liberties in Wartime
Review: The bulk of this dispassionate account of how civil liberties have fared during times of conflict is devoted to Civil War events, including Vallandigham's arrest, treason trials in Indianapolis, and the legal response to Lincoln's assassination. New in softcover.

Title: The Popular Press
Teaser: Popular Press The
Review: The Civil War coincided with improvements in printing technology and mass-marketed "penny newspapers." This installment in the History of American Journalism series finds that Lincolns press strategy, which "seemed to encourage fighting among editors," foreshadowed modern "spin."

Title: The Fighting Men of the Civil War
Teaser: Fighting Men of the Civil War The
Review:
The common soldier's experience of battle, indeed his whole life under arms, is the subject of Davis' fascinating account. Camp life, uniforms, weapons, and a host of personal items are featured in a series of specially commissioned photographs -- together with illustrations of the arms, armament, and uniforms of both Confederate and Federal forces.

84 color & 182 b&w photographs, oversize

Title: The Heart Calls Home
Teaser: Heart Calls Home The
Review: The concluding work in Joyce Hansen's trilogy about the endurance of love in troubled times, The Heart Calls Home recounts the story of escaped slave and Union veteran Obi Booker. Booker returns to South Carolina during Reconstruction in search of the woman he loves, ever mindful of his obligation to aid other freedmen.

Title: Tomorrow's Promise: (Pinkerton Lady Chronicles)
Review: The concluding work in the Pinkerton Lady Chronicles series, Tomorrow's Promise shows intrepid reporter and secret agent Laurel Bartlett on the trail of a Copperhead murderer who really is out to get her.

Title: Antislavery Violence Sectional, Racial, and Cultural Conflict in Antebellum America
Teaser: Antislavery Violence Sectional, Racial, and Cultural Conflict in Antebellum America
Review: The essays collected in Antislavery Violence focus on militant resistance to slavery by southern slave rebels, antislavery women in Kansas, and northern antislavery politicians in the decades preceding the War.

Title: The Civil War: A Narrative
Teaser: Civil War: A Narrative The
Review:
The essential gift for Civil War buffs, Shelby Foote's three-volume series The Civil War: A Narrative is divided as follows:

Volume I: Fort Sumter to Perryville;

Volume II: Fredericksburg to Meridian;

Volume III: Red River to Appomattox.

Title: The Civil War: A Narrative: Volume I: Fort Sumter to Perryville
Teaser: Civil War: A Narrative: Volume I: Fort Sumter to Perryville The
Review:
The essential gift for Civil War buffs, Shelby Foote's three-volume series The Civil War: A Narrative is divided as follows:

Volume I: Fort Sumter to Perryville;

Volume II: Fredericksburg to Meridian;

Volume III: Red River to Appomattox.

Title: The Civil War: A Narrative: Volume II: Fredericksburg to Meridian
Teaser: Civil War: A Narrative: Volume II: Fredericksburg to Meridian The
Review:
The essential gift for Civil War buffs, Shelby Foote's three-volume series The Civil War: A Narrative is divided as follows:

Volume I: Fort Sumter to Perryville;

Volume II: Fredericksburg to Meridian;

Volume III: Red River to Appomattox.

Title: The Civil War: A Narrative: Volume III: Red River to Appomattox
Teaser: Civil War: A Narrative: Volume III: Red River to Appomattox The
Review:
The essential gift for Civil War buffs, Shelby Foote's three-volume series The Civil War: A Narrative is divided as follows:

Volume I: Fort Sumter to Perryville;

Volume II: Fredericksburg to Meridian;

Volume III: Red River to Appomattox.

Title: The Union Preserved: A Guide to Civil War Records in the New York State Archives
Teaser: Union Preserved: A Guide to Civil War Records in the New York State Archives The
Review: The expansive artifacts and primary material held by the New York State Museum, the New York State Library, the New York State Archives, and the New York State Division of Military and Naval Affairs are featured in this comprehensive, illustrated reference work.

Title: Disaster in Deep Sand: The Red River Expedition
Teaser: Disaster in Deep Sand: The Red River Expedition
Review: The expedition's purpose was simple: disrupt cotton production along Louisiana's Red River. Anders describes how shallow water and poor decisions led to the defeat of the numerically superior Union force.

Title: The Tarnished Cavalier: Major General Earl Van Dorn, C.S.A.
Teaser: Tarnished Cavalier: Major General Earl Van Dorn, C.S.A. The
Review: The first study in more than 30 years of Major General Earl Van Dorn, C.S.A. uses previously unpublished material to provide a balanced view of this dashing, controversial, and sometimes overlooked leader of the Western theater.

Title: Lincoln and the Abolition of Slavery
Review: The five volumes that compose the American War Library's Civil War series survey the conflict's causes, leaders, battles, and outcome. In Lincoln and the Abolition of Slavery, Russell Roberts uses John Brown, the 1860 election, and the role of blacks in the War to explicate slavery's role in the festering regional hostilities. Diane Yancey sketches the lives of politicians, abolitionists, military commanders, and prominent women in Leaders of the North and South. Weapon technology, cavalry equipment, artillery, naval warfare, and espionage are featured in Weapons of War by Gail B. Stewart. Seven key battles or campaigns are discussed in Diane Yancey's Strategic Battles, along with ironclad engagements and postwar reunions. The common soldiers' perspective is depicted in James A. Corrick's Life Among the Soldiers and Cavalry through such experiences as enlistment, camp food, grooming, and mutiny. Although the books overlap in some places, they generally complement each other in subject matter. Each volume offers footnotes and interesting sidebars about topics such as the Whig party and General Meade's horse Old Baldy. Some include a glossary or a chronology. Overall, the series would enrich a middle school-level library or bookshelf.

Title: Leaders of the North and South
Review: The five volumes that compose the American War Library's Civil War series survey the conflict's causes, leaders, battles, and outcome. In Lincoln and the Abolition of Slavery, Russell Roberts uses John Brown, the 1860 election, and the role of blacks in the War to explicate slavery's role in the festering regional hostilities. Although the books overlap in some places, they generally complement each other in subject matter. Each volume offers footnotes and interesting sidebars about topics such as the Whig party and General Meade's horse Old Baldy. Some include a glossary or a chronology. Overall, the series would enrich a middle school-level library or bookshelf.

Each volume offers footnotes and interesting sidebars about topics such as the Whig party and General Meade's horse Old Baldy. Some include a glossary or a chronology. Overall, the series would enrich a middle school-level library or bookshelf.

Title: Strategic Battles

Each volume offers footnotes and interesting sidebars about topics such as the Whig party and General Meade's horse Old Baldy. Some include a glossary or a chronology. Overall, the series would enrich a middle school-level library or bookshelf.

Title: Life Among the Soldiers and Cavalry
Review: The five volumes that compose the American War Library's Civil War series survey the conflict's causes, leaders, battles, and outcome. In Lincoln and the Abolition of Slavery, Russell Roberts uses John Brown, the 1860 election, and the role of blacks in the War to explicate slavery's role in the festering regional hostilities. Diane Yancey sketches the lives of politicians, abolitionists, military commanders, and prominent women in Leaders of the North and South. Weapon technology, cavalry equipment, artillery, naval warfare, and espionage are featured in Weapons of War by Gail B. Stewart. Seven key battles or campaigns are discussed in Diane Yancey's Strategic Battles, along with ironclad engagements and postwar reunions. The common soldiers' perspective is depicted in James A. Corrick's Life Among the Soldiers and Cavalry through such experiences as enlistment, camp food, grooming, and mutiny. Although the books overlap in some places, they generally complement each other in subject matter. Each volume offers footnotes and interesting sidebars about topics such as the Whig party and General Meade's horse Old Baldy. Some include a glossary or a chronology. Overall, the series would enrich a middle school-level library or bookshelf.

Title: The Gray Riders: Stories from the Confederate Cavalry
Teaser: Gray Riders: Stories from the Confederate Cavalry The
Review: The Gray Riders is a collection of multiple accounts from various cavalrymen throughout the Confederacy, relating their experiences. It recalls the victories, defeats, and interesting activities of Confederate horse soldiers.

Title: The Papers of Jefferson Davis, Volume 10: October 1863-August 1864
Teaser: Papers of Jefferson Davis, Volume 10: October 1863-August 1864 The
Review: The military and political affairs of the Confederacy for ten crucial months -- spanning from Chickamauga to Atlanta -- are captured in Volume 10 of Davis's Papers. "You know how constantly I am occupied," he lamented to one correspondent. Nevertheless, the volume of his correspondence is impressive.

Title: Days of Defiance: Sumter, Secession, and the Coming of the Civil War
Teaser: Days of Defiance: Sumter, Secession, and the Coming of the Civil War
Review: The paperback edition of a narrative account of the period between the election of Abraham Lincoln and the attack on Fort Sumter. Klein focuses on the men who instigated the conflict, but failed to foresee the bloody struggle their actions would produce.

Title: Pinpoint Guide to Alabama & Florida Civil War Sites
Teaser: Pinpoint Guide to Alabama & Florida Civil War Sites
Review: The Pinpoint Guides to Civil War sites series contains 18 unique guides that combine the convenience of a foldout map with the detailed information of a textbook. Written by lifetime Civil War enthusiast James J. Condra, these guides make the Civil War intelligible to the non -- Civil War buff by featuring Civil War sites and other attractions with major significance, such as houses and museums.  The guides also include detailed directions to the sites, hours of operation, admission information, and phone numbers.

Title: Pinpoint Guide to the Atlanta Campaign Civil War Sites
Teaser: Pinpoint Guide to the Atlanta Campaign Civil War Sites
Review: The Pinpoint Guides to Civil War sites series contains 18 unique guides that combine the convenience of a foldout map with the detailed information of a textbook. Written by lifetime Civil War enthusiast James J. Condra, these guides make the Civil War intelligible to the non -- Civil War buff by featuring Civil War sites and other attractions with major significance, such as houses and museums.  The guides also include detailed directions to the sites, hours of operation, admission information, and phone numbers.

Title: Pinpoint Guide to Atlanta: The March to the Sea Civil War Sites
Teaser: Pinpoint Guide to Atlanta: The March to the Sea Civil War Sites
Review: The Pinpoint Guides to Civil War sites series contains 18 unique guides that combine the convenience of a foldout map with the detailed information of a textbook. Written by lifetime Civil War enthusiast James J. Condra, these guides make the Civil War intelligible to the non -- Civil War buff by featuring Civil War sites and other attractions with major significance, such as houses and museums.  The guides also include detailed directions to the sites, hours of operation, admission information, and phone numbers.

Title: Pinpoint Guide to Mississippi Civil War Sites
Teaser: Pinpoint Guide to Mississippi Civil War Sites
Review: The Pinpoint Guides to Civil War sites series contains 18 unique guides that combine the convenience of a foldout map with the detailed information of a textbook. Written by lifetime Civil War enthusiast James J. Condra, these guides make the Civil War intelligible to the non -- Civil War buff by featuring Civil War sites and other attractions with major significance, such as houses and museums.  The guides also include detailed directions to the sites, hours of operation, admission information, and phone numbers.

Title: Pinpoint Guide to North & South Carolina Civil War Sites
Teaser: Pinpoint Guide to North Carolina & South Carolina Civil War Sites
Review: The Pinpoint Guides to Civil War sites series contains 18 unique guides that combine the convenience of a foldout map with the detailed information of a textbook. Written by lifetime Civil War enthusiast James J. Condra, these guides make the Civil War intelligible to the non -- Civil War buff by featuring Civil War sites and other attractions with major significance, such as houses and museums.  The guides also include detailed directions to the sites, hours of operation, admission information, and phone numbers.

Title: Pinpoint Guide to Virginia: Richmond to Appomattox Civil War Sites
Teaser: Pinpoint Guide to Virginia: Richmond to Appomattox Civil War Sites
Review: The Pinpoint Guides to Civil War sites series contains 18 unique guides that combine the convenience of a foldout map with the detailed information of a textbook. Written by lifetime Civil War enthusiast James J. Condra, these guides make the Civil War intelligible to the non -- Civil War buff by featuring Civil War sites and other attractions with major significance, such as houses and museums.  The guides also include detailed directions to the sites, hours of operation, admission information, and phone numbers.

Title: Agent of Destiny: The Life and Times of General Winfield Scott
Review: The prolific life of Winfield Scott, who first gained fame as one of the few bright spots in the War of 1812. Scott served fourteen presidents, led the invasion of Mexico, and for a short time commanded the Union Army.

Title: William Clarke Quantrill: His Life and Times
Teaser: William Clarke Quantrill: His Life and Times
Review: The Quantrill legend is rooted in acts of savage violence throughout Kansas and Missouri during the Civil War -- deeds both romanticized and vilified. Castel traces Quantrill's rise to power, from Kansas border ruffian and Confederate Army captain to lawless leader of "the most formidable band of revolver fighters the West ever knew."

Title: Burden of Honor
Teaser: Burden of Honor
Review: The story of three youth -- Gideon, Emily, and Nat -- who remain true to friendships and family obligations despite the conflict around them, this novel demonstrates that the virtues of honesty, determination, and courage need not be casualties of war. Ages 11-14.

Title: The Hairstons: An American Family in Black and White
Teaser: Hairstons: An American Family in Black and White The
Review: The two branches of the Hairston family differed in color but shared a surname that attested to their irrevocably intertwined fortunes. This account of the family's history spans the antebellum to Civil Rights eras.

Title: Life of a Slave on a Southern Plantation
Review: The Way People Live, a book series for young people based on primary resources, tries "to flesh out the traditional, two-dimensional views of people in various . . . historical circum-stances . . . to enrich our understanding of ourselves." Two new additions, Life on the Under-ground Railroad and Life of a Slave, apply this approach to slavery, combining historical narrative with sidebar descriptions of such things as slave clothing and slave names.

Title: Lightning Time
Teaser: Lightning Time
Review: Theodore Worth is a young teenager growing up in the North prior to the Civil War. Believing that he can make a difference, he joins John Brown's army but eventually discovers that there are other ways to fight -- instead of a gun he uses lightning!

Title: Palmetto Leaves
Teaser: Palmetto Leaves
Review: These literary sketches were originally published as monthly dispatches in the Christian Union. Stowe tells of her new life of leisure and adventure on the St. Johns River -- near what is now Jacksonville, Florida -- during the Reconstruction years.

Title: Brave Decisions: Fifteen Profiles in Courage and Character from American Military History
Teaser: Brave Decisions: Fifteen Profiles in Courage and Character from American Military History
Review: These well-crafted sketches of soldiers who faced difficult decisions include prominent generals, Paddy O'Rorke of the 140th New York, and gunboat commander Henry Walke.

Title: Civil War Texas: A History and a Guide
Teaser: Civil War Texas:  A History and a Guide
Review: This accessible monograph provides an illustrated narrative of the War in Texas, from the 1861 secession ordinance to Kirby Smith's surrender at Galveston. It features sideboxes, maps, a chronology of events, and an index.

Title: John Charles Fremont: Character as Destiny
Review: This biography examines the life of explorer, general, and first Republican presidential candidate John Charles Fremont. Rolle explores the psychological complexities of the man and the controversies that followed throughout his life.

Title: Phil Sheridan and His Army
Teaser: Phil Sheridan and His Army
Review: This biography focuses on Sheridan's frontier Indian fighting. By the end of his career, Hutton observes, Sheridan proved that he "could be as strong a defender of the Indians as he had earlier been an advocate of relentless war upon them."

Title: Reminiscences of Winfield Scott Hancock
Teaser: Reminiscences of Winfield Scott Hancock
Review: This biography follows Hancock from his rise to general to nomination as the 1880 Democratic presidential candidate. Written by his wife, it includes accounts of disease and injury, as well as personal letters.

Title: Witness to an Era: The Life and Photos of Alexander Gardner
Teaser: Witness to an Era: The Life and Photos of Alexander Gardner
Review: This biography of America's first photojournalist is a tribute to Alexander Gardner's amazing talent. Filled with fascinating photos -- many never before published -- this collection includes some of the War's most memorable photos.

Title: George Washington Grayson and the Creek Nation: 1853-1920
Teaser: George Washington Grayson and the Creek Nation: 1853-1920
Review: This biography of pro-Confederate Creek leader George Washington Grayson includes a chapter on Civil War activity in the Indian Territory, which "cost the Creek Nation dearly."

Title: Sisters Against Slavery: A Story About Sarah and Angelina Grimk
Teaser: Sisters Against Slavery: A Story About Sarah and Angelina Grimk
Review: This biography of the Grimk sisters recounts their prominent abolitionist activities in the decades preceding the War, and their late life activism as women's suffragists.

Title: The Limits of Dissent: Clement L. Vallandigham & the Civil War
Review: This biography's subject is a congressman from Ohio whose opposition to Lincoln led to an 1863 military court conviction for the "habit of declaring sympathy for the enemy." Despite Vallan-digham's brilliant defense of civil liberties, "time vindicated Lincoln, not Vallandigham."

Title: The Libby Prison Diary of Colonel Emeric Szabad
Teaser: Libby Prison Diary of Colonel Emeric Szabad The
Review: This book covers Szabad's five months of captivity between October 1863 and March 1864. Written in an analytical style by a highly literate, Hungarian-born educator, this diary enriches our understanding of Libby Prison.

Title: With Courage and Delicacy: Civil War on the Peninsula
Teaser: With Courage and Delicacy: Civil War on the Peninsula
Review: This book depicts the Yankee women infused with the spirit of evangelical Christianity who organized the U.S. Sanitary Commission to collect medical and sanitary supplies; they also served as floating hospital nurses during the Peninsula campaign.

Title: The Battlefields of the Civil War
Teaser: Battlefields of the Civil War The
Review: This book tells the stories of thirteen of the most important battles of the Civil War, including Gettysburg. Each battle is illustrated with an annotated, full-page color map showing troop movements, positions of commanders, and geographic features.  Also included are 35 full-page color photographic spreads of Civil War artifacts, 28 full-page color paintings, and 166 historical photographs.
